snippet: The money, from a group of philanthropic organizations, could also relieve the city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts from having to sell works to pay the city’s debts.
abstract: Federal mediators say national and local philanthropic foundations have committed $330 million toward deal to avoid cuts to Detroit retirees' pensions and to save city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts' renowned collection; experts say plan is a first both in the foundation world, which has not been a source of money to shore up public-sector pensions in the past, and in the municipal bankruptcy cases.

byline.original: By RANDY KENNEDY, MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

lead_paragraph: The money, from a group of philanthropic organizations, could also relieve the city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts from having to sell works to pay the city’s debts.
